Comment: In this game, I blunderd badly in the opening, and somehow I managed to survive by attacking up to the last with the very last pawn...

I just don't know how to play the English, and since I play the Budapest, I am not experienced in this kind of scheme. Now I play uncommitedly, assuming the fianchetto is not bad, but I'm not sure. Theory has to say something about that, for sure.

A loss of time, but it is not easy to cash it. A pawn storm can be dangerous...
Let's start the fires. If I have my bishop on b2 first, I allow him to b4, and now c5.
I can't afford to close the d column right now, so I have to... close it!

Closing it, but in a nasty way. If white exchanges, the white diagonal is closed by a black pawn, so I don't care to lose a tempo playing Bb7 if not necessary. And my bishop will have the c8 - h3 diag to look at.
Now, I didn't want to have the c pawn not on the c column, so I dared to play...
...of course, this is the result.
...of course, this is the result.
Ok, so what? I just overlooked the Nxc7 treath.
?? c6 was advisable.
?? c6 was advisable.

Now, what would you do? I have a spare tempo that whorts a rook, and, maybe, a knight. How can I spend it? I can move Ba4, exchanging BxN, but is seemed ugly to me. Without a bishop... So I adventured...
